comment_text.mn149:1.1: This discourse is “great” because it integrates multiple distinct teaching frameworks within the six sense fields. These include the majority of the saṁyutta-mātikā, the list of topics making up the Saṁyutta Nikāya.
comment_text.mn149:2.1: For āyatanika see MN 121:10.5, where it refers to the life faculty of the body that is “related to the six sense fields”; there are also heavens and hells “related to the six fields of contact” (MN 50:22.2, Sb 35:35.135). In each case it refers to something that is connected to or related to the six sense fields, as indicated by the suffix ika. Here this refers to the fact that this discourse treats multiple distinct teaching frameworks in relation to the six sense fields. These include the majority of the saṁyutta-mātikā, the list of topics making up the Saṁyutta Nikāya. And this inclusive and integrative nature in turn explains why the teaching is “great”.
comment_text.mn149:3.2: In other words, one who becomes attached to sense experience creates kamma that generates a new life consisting of the five aggregates. This passage integrates the teachings on the six sense fields and the five aggregates under the first noble truth, as well as briefly implying the basic principle of dependent origination.
comment_text.mn149:3.3: This is the second noble truth.
comment_text.mn149:10.8: The eightfold path is brought in as well, along with the other main teachings of the path.
comment_text.mn149:10.11: This refers to the distinct functions to be exercised in relation to each of the four noble truths (SN 56.11:5.1).

translation_text.mn149:0.2: The Great Discourse on What Relates to the Six Sense Fields
translation_text.mn149:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn149:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn149:2.1: “Mendicants, I shall teach you the great discourse on what relates to the six sense fields.
translation_text.mn149:2.2: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn149:3.1: “Mendicants, when you don’t truly know and see the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, and what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral that arises dependent on eye contact, you’re aroused by these things.
translation_text.mn149:3.2: Someone who lives aroused like this—fettered, confused, concentrating on gratification—accumulates the five grasping aggregates for themselves in the future.
translation_text.mn149:3.3: And their craving—which leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands—grows.
translation_text.mn149:3.7: And they experience physical and mental suffering.
translation_text.mn149:4-7.1: When you don’t truly know and see the ear …
translation_text.mn149:4-7.5: mind, ideas, mind consciousness, mind contact, and what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral that arises dependent on mind contact, you’re aroused by these things.
translation_text.mn149:8.1: Someone who lives aroused like this—fettered, confused, concentrating on gratification—accumulates the five grasping aggregates for themselves in the future.
translation_text.mn149:8.2: And their craving—which leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands—grows.
translation_text.mn149:8.6: And they experience physical and mental suffering.
translation_text.mn149:9.1: When you do truly know and see the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, and what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral that arises dependent on eye contact, you’re not aroused by these things.
translation_text.mn149:9.2: Someone who lives unaroused like this—unfettered, unconfused, concentrating on drawbacks—disperses the five grasping aggregates for themselves in the future.
translation_text.mn149:9.3: And their craving—which leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands—is given up.
translation_text.mn149:9.7: And they experience physical and mental pleasure.
translation_text.mn149:10.1: The view of such a person is right view.
translation_text.mn149:10.5: and their immersion is right immersion.
translation_text.mn149:10.6: And their actions of body and speech, and their livelihood, have already been fully purified before.
translation_text.mn149:10.7: So this noble eightfold path is fully developed.
translation_text.mn149:10.8: When the noble eightfold path is developed, the following are fully developed: the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties, the five powers, and the seven awakening factors.
translation_text.mn149:10.9: And these two qualities proceed in conjunction:
translation_text.mn149:10.11: They completely understand by direct knowledge those things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge.
translation_text.mn149:10.12: They give up by direct knowledge those things that should be given up by direct knowledge.
translation_text.mn149:10.13: They develop by direct knowledge those things that should be developed by direct knowledge.
translation_text.mn149:10.14: They realize by direct knowledge those things that should be realized by direct knowledge.
translation_text.mn149:11.1: And what are the things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge?
translation_text.mn149:11.2: You should say: ‘The five grasping aggregates.’
translation_text.mn149:11.3: That is: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
translation_text.mn149:11.4: These are the things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge.
translation_text.mn149:11.5: And what are the things that should be given up by direct knowledge?
translation_text.mn149:11.6: Ignorance and craving for continued existence.
translation_text.mn149:11.7: These are the things that should be given up by direct knowledge.
translation_text.mn149:11.8: And what are the things that should be developed by direct knowledge?
translation_text.mn149:11.10: These are the things that should be developed by direct knowledge.
translation_text.mn149:11.11: And what are the things that should be realized by direct knowledge?
translation_text.mn149:11.13: These are the things that should be realized by direct knowledge.
translation_text.mn149:12-18.1: When you truly know and see the ear …
translation_text.mn149:12-18.5: mind, ideas, mind consciousness, mind contact, and what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral that arises dependent on mind contact, you are not aroused by these things. …
translation_text.mn149:26.3: These are the things that should be realized by direct knowledge.”
translation_text.mn149:26.4: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn149:26.5: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
